title: Climate change drives economic damage, extreme weather, and environmental challenges, demanding global action.

details.text: Climate change is driving up property damage and insurance costs, risking a $25trn hit to global wealth and stability. Homeowners and governments face rising repair and upgrade expenses.
The Great Barrier Reef faces severe coral bleaching from record-high sea temperatures, risking biodiversity and the economy. Restoration efforts may not suffice if global warming continues.
Severe floods in Brazil's Rio Grande do Sul have killed 150, left 130 missing, and displaced 600,000. The disaster threatens key crops and highlights the impact of climate change.
Last year was the hottest on record, with 2024 set to be even hotter. El Niño boosts temperatures, but La Niña may cool things later. Fossil fuels drive this trend.
New research shows climate change could slash global GDP by 12% per 1°C rise, far worse than earlier estimates. The social cost of carbon may be over $1,000 per tonne, urging radical action.
China's carbon emissions hit a record in 2023 but are now falling. Economic growth is decoupling from emissions, driven by clean energy and electric vehicles, though more radical changes are needed.
Canada's wildfires in 2023 burned 185,000 sq km, releasing 1,800 megatonnes of CO2. The country is now using drones, indigenous practices, and "firesmart" measures to combat future blazes.

Australia is investing A$23bn in clean energy to counter fossil-fuel job losses, aiming to become a renewable energy leader. Key focus: green hydrogen, critical minerals, and reducing China dependence.
Sea levels have risen 21-24cm since 1880, threatening coasts. Controversial geoengineering ideas aim to slow ice melt but face scientific, political, and financial challenges.
Researchers are breeding heat-resistant corals to combat bleaching, with 100,000 baby corals reintroduced in the largest restoration trial ever. Can science save our reefs?
Panama relocates 300 families from Gardi Sugdub to the mainland due to rising sea levels. The new settlement offers better living conditions, setting a precedent for climate-driven relocations.
High-tech sails, like Flettner rotors and giant kites, are cutting fuel costs and emissions in shipping, with potential savings up to 60%, aiding the industry in meeting global emission targets.
Cunard's Queen Anne christening marks cruise industry's post-pandemic rebound. Bookings rise, but environmental concerns and destination strains grow. New offerings attract first-timers.
British Columbia halts jade mining due to environmental concerns and declining demand, influenced by the Tahltan Nation and fluctuating Chinese interest.

Governor Kathy Hochul halted New York's $15 congestion charge, citing financial concerns for working- and middle-class families. This decision impacts subway funding and may deter other US cities from similar measures.
Two cicada broods are emerging together in the eastern US for the first time this century. This event offers scientists a rare chance to study their interactions and the effects of climate change.

title: Middle East conflicts escalate with violence in Gaza and Sudan, air strikes causing international outrage, and strained diplomacy.

details.text: Joe Biden backs an Israeli ceasefire plan with Hamas, facing opposition from Netanyahu's hardliners. The plan aims to free hostages and rebuild Gaza, but Hamas's acceptance is uncertain.
Israel's Gaza invasion weakened Hamas but caused civilian suffering and strained international relations. Domestic politics are in turmoil, and long-term peace remains elusive.
El-Fasher, Darfur's capital, faces severe violence as the RSF attacks, trapping 2.8 million people. The fall could lead to ethnic cleansing and shift power in Sudan's civil war.
An Israeli air strike in Rafah killed dozens, sparking international outrage. Conflicting reports on the target and Israel's defiance of an ICJ order add to the tension.
Sudan's conflict between the SAF and RSF has led to 17,000 deaths, 9 million displaced, and looming famine. Economic collapse and minimal global media coverage worsen the crisis.
The Israeli offensive in Rafah has cut aid to Gaza, worsening conditions for 2.2 million Palestinians. Critics hold Israel responsible for the rising hunger and disease.

Iran's leadership crisis impacts its nuclear programme, raising regional arms race fears. The IAEA faces challenges in Iran, Ukraine, and Syria, while global nuclear projects grow amid safety concerns.
Global defence spending surged by 6.8%, the highest since 2009. NATO, excluding America, boosted budgets by $68bn. Only 18 NATO members will meet the 2% GDP target this year.

Oil prices have stayed stable despite Middle East conflicts and OPEC cuts, thanks to diversified production, rerouted Russian oil, and OPEC's spare capacity, with demand tempered by China's slow growth and electric vehicles.
Transnistria, a pro-Russian region in Moldova, faces rising tensions post-Ukraine invasion. Economic struggles, leadership divides, and complex Moldova ties threaten regional stability.
Jihadist groups like IS are resurging, exploiting conflicts and using tech to spread terror. Western intelligence faces new challenges as geopolitical shifts complicate containment efforts.
The Ukraine Recovery Conference in Berlin stressed urgent aid needs, with Zelensky seeking energy and air-defence systems. The World Bank estimates $486bn for repairs, far beyond Ukraine's budget.
Israel faces diplomatic challenges as the ICC seeks arrest warrants for its leaders and the ICJ orders limits on military actions in Rafah, highlighting its growing isolation.
Iran's June 28th election sees six candidates, with reformists gaining momentum after Ebrahim Raisi's death. The Guardian Council's control and disqualifications shape the power struggle.
Benny Gantz and Gadi Eisenkot quit Israel's war cabinet, frustrated with Netanyahu's Gaza strategy. Their exit pressures Netanyahu, who now relies on far-right allies amid US calls for a ceasefire.
Zelensky’s Global Peace Summit faces delays and key absences but will host 90 delegations to discuss food and nuclear security. Alternative talks may involve Saudi Arabia and the Vatican.
Russia's firepower strains Ukraine's defences. A $40bn US aid package aims to bolster Ukraine, but challenges in manpower, air defence, and training persist. Fierce battles continue in Chasiv Yar.
Ukraine's use of long-range missiles and drones has crippled Russian military assets in Crimea, pressuring Putin and testing the region's security as Russian holidaymakers reconsider visits.
Despite Iran's anti-West stance, many elite children live in the West, revealing contradictions and potential impacts on Iran's presidential election.
Israeli commandos rescued four hostages from Gaza, but future missions are unlikely. Antony Blinken's ceasefire plan faces hurdles as Hamas and Israel remain divided, and Israeli ministers resign.
OPEC's overproduction is failing to keep oil prices high, with key members exceeding quotas. Rising global stocks and new non-OPEC supply in 2025 threaten market stability.
Ethiopian migrants to Saudi Arabia face extreme dangers, including abuse and death, driven by economic desperation and misinformation, with minimal international aid and support.
Hizbullah's rocket and drone attacks spark wildfires in Israel, while Israeli shelling ignites forests in Lebanon. Both sides prefer diplomacy, but tensions and economic concerns persist.
On June 6, 2023, explosives destroyed Ukraine's Kakhovka dam, causing massive floods and environmental damage. Ukraine blames Russia. A year later, debates on rebuilding continue.
Since Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, the Caucasus and Central Asia have seen economic growth from Russian influx, but rising local tensions and declining public opinion of Russia.
Somaliland's deal with Ethiopia could lead to recognition of its independence, but faces internal dissent, regional tension, and unresolved terms, all amid upcoming elections.
Ahod Ebrahim leads Bangsamoro, a region in Mindanao with improved stability and poverty reduction since a 2014 peace deal. Challenges remain with disarmament and reintegration of former fighters.
Unrest in New Caledonia, fueled by international disinformation and a new French law, prompts President Macron's urgent visit. Historical grievances and strategic stakes heighten tensions.

Saudi Aramco, the world's largest energy firm, is investing billions in cleaner oil, natural gas, petrochemicals, and green tech to diversify Saudi Arabia's economy and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.

title: America's political scene is turbulent with Trump's legal issues, Biden's low approval, and elections testing democracy and nuclear policies.

details.text: The Supreme Court's reversal of Roe v Wade has ignited a grassroots movement, with women leading efforts to add abortion rights referendums to ballots in key states, impacting future elections.
America's nuclear deterrence faces challenges from great-power rivalry, fraying arms-control, and potential Trump return. Allies in Asia and Europe reconsider their nuclear options.
America's economy has grown 8% since 2019, outpacing Europe and Japan. Inflation is falling, labour force and productivity are up, but rising debt and financial risks loom.
Donald Trump's felony conviction highlights that no one is above the law but deepens political divides. Both campaigns use the trial to seek donations, with Trump still leading in polls.
Around 4 billion people are voting this year, testing global democracy. Key elections in Russia, India, and the U.S. face challenges from interference and misinformation.
Donald Trump faces sentencing for falsifying records, but his support among Republicans remains strong. Swing voters focus on everyday issues, not his legal troubles.
A new model predicts a two in three chance of Trump winning the election, with key states shifting in his favour due to economic concerns like inflation and job security.

Joe Biden's approval rating is at 39%, trailing Trump in key states. The Economist's model gives Biden a one-in-three chance of re-election, with Trump favoured in swing states and even some Democratic strongholds.
Narendra Modi's BJP wins but loses seats, forcing coalition reliance. Voters prioritize economy over nationalism. Modi's next move will shape India's future and global role.
The article examines the risk of authoritarianism in America, noting how presidential powers could be misused to undermine democracy, despite constitutional checks and balances.
Donald Trump's potential return to the White House raises global concerns, with possible shifts in tariffs, support for Ukraine and Taiwan, and a transactional approach to allies and adversaries.
America's debt has surged to 96% of GDP, with rising interest rates worsening the deficit. Biden and Trump ignore the issue, risking severe economic consequences.
Biden and Trump face off in a crucial debate on June 27th. Biden aims to shift polling dynamics and counter Trump's attacks, while voters' nostalgia for Trump's presidency adds to the stakes.
America's democracy, deemed "flawed" since 2016, faces deepening mistrust and polarisation. Over 80% see officials as out of touch, with autocracy gaining some favour. Challenges persist.
Donald Trump struggles to secure full Republican support for 2024, facing resistance from both far-right and moderate factions, despite strategic endorsements and polling leads.
Third-party candidates could sway the tight Biden-Trump race, with figures like Cornel West and Jill Stein potentially impacting key swing states. Voter turnout and ballot access are crucial.
Donald Trump's conviction has unified Republicans, boosting his lead in the presidential race and campaign funds, while exposing party divisions and prompting muted Democratic responses.
Wisconsin's new legislative maps, signed by Governor Tony Evers, undo gerrymandering, boosting Democrats' chances in state races and potentially aiding Joe Biden in this key swing state.
American consumers have driven GDP growth, but spending is now declining. Credit card debt rises, especially in Florida. Wealthier Americans remain unaffected. Future hinges on income growth.
President Biden's new order to deny asylum to illegal migrants marks a conservative shift, faces legal challenges, and may not curb crossings, highlighting political motives ahead of elections.
John Bolton says Trump lacks consistent foreign policy, driven by moods. His unpredictable nature and advisers' conflicting ideologies complicate forecasts, impacting NATO, Ukraine, and China.
Conflicting job surveys show 1.2 million new jobs vs. 100,000 lost. Fed favours payroll data, delaying rate cuts. Rising unemployment and sector shifts hint at economic changes.
Donald Trump was found guilty of falsifying business records related to hush-money payments in 2016. Despite the conviction, his presidential campaign may not be significantly affected.
The BJP aims for 400 seats in the next election, with polls predicting 388. Congress, despite alliances, is expected to win only 118. Modi remains popular, but BJP struggles in the south.
Narendra Modi's BJP misjudged economic and caste issues in the recent election, losing ground to an opposition focused on caste. The BJP's future hinges on addressing these concerns.

The BJP and allies fell short of a majority, losing key seats in the north. Anti-Muslim rhetoric failed, and rural voters focused on unemployment and inflation. The opposition's smart strategies paid off.
Peter Navarro, jailed for contempt of Congress, still shapes Trump's trade policies, pushing for high tariffs and aggressive protectionism, influencing even Biden's measures.
Narendra Modi is poised for a third term amid a contentious election, Western hesitance to criticise, and rising concerns over India's democracy and human rights.
Narendra Modi's new cabinet signals policy continuity, but faces challenges from coalition partners, opposition demands, and internal BJP disunity.
Narendra Modi's BJP won 292 seats, falling short of a majority. Losses in key states reflect voter concerns, leading to a more complex coalition and less predictable policymaking.

Exit polls predict a decisive BJP victory, securing a third term for Narendra Modi, with significant gains in new regions. The opposition coalition led by Congress is not expected to challenge the BJP.
Hunter Biden was convicted for buying a gun while addicted to drugs, facing up to 25 years. Joe Biden won't pardon him. Another trial for tax evasion looms, with political implications.

Budget scorekeepers like the CBO and JCT face criticism for their methods, sparking a debate on budget model accuracy and the creation of alternatives. The complexity of fiscal predictions remains a challenge.
Narendra Modi's BJP taps India's 18 million-strong diaspora for political clout, leveraging rallies and remittances to boost his global image and outshine Congress's domestic focus.
Rishi Sunak and Sir Keir Starmer's lack of charisma highlights flaws in the presidential style of British politics, risking the rise of extremist figures and altering the political landscape.
Mexico's diaspora in the U.S. sees rising electoral participation, with candidates targeting émigrés who often vote against the ruling party. Online voting and remittances boost their influence.
Tony Blair's New Labour embraced globalisation, but Keir Starmer's Labour now favours "homeland economics," focusing on national security, self-sufficiency, and reviving blue-collar jobs.
Labour targets 174 Tory seats and 11 of its own with large South Asian populations, amid concerns over eroding support among Hindu and Muslim voters, influenced by stances on Gaza and recent losses.
Chicago's mayor, Brandon Johnson, faces low approval despite a drop in the murder rate. His radical policies and financial woes, including a $391m school deficit, challenge his leadership.
Cairo, Illinois, faces collapse as America's population growth slows, with local governments struggling to adapt. Internal migration to Sunbelt states worsens the decline.
Hartlepool, once a Labour stronghold, is set to return to Labour amid local discontent over stalled public projects and deteriorating services, reflecting broader political volatility.
Nigel Farage aims to reshape the British right by leading Reform UK, targeting former Tory voters with tough immigration policies, and standing for Parliament in Clacton.
Canvey Island, the UK's most Conservative area, blends mock Tudor charm with apathy towards politics. With an aging population, it reflects broader trends in seaside towns.
Nigel Farage leads Reform UK, aiming to cut immigration and address Britain's decline. His return could boost the party's poll numbers and reshape the centre-right political landscape.

title: China's global influence grows through strategic alliances, technological progress, and economic initiatives, despite geopolitical hurdles.

details.text: "World on the Brink" advises America to counter China by controlling chip exports, diversifying supply chains, and shifting defence spending to scalable tools, while leveraging demographic and geopolitical strengths.
America and China resume military talks to prevent conflict in Asia, despite tensions over Taiwan. Key meeting at Shangri-La Dialogue aims to re-establish crucial communication.
William Lai Ching-te's inauguration as Taiwan's president sparks hopes for global recognition, vows to maintain sovereignty, strengthen defences, and navigate tensions with China.
Russia's arms industry thrives despite Western sanctions, bolstered by Chinese components and third-country imports. Defence spending rises, but long-term sustainability is uncertain.
China's $48bn semiconductor fund aims to boost its chip industry, but US export restrictions and design challenges hinder progress. Western firms still lead in complex semiconductors.
The tech wars between America and China reshape global supply chains, focusing on chipmaking and green tech, with potential economic and geopolitical impacts.
Xi Jinping's Europe visit, his first since 2019, underscores China's grievances with the West, highlights strategic ties with Serbia and Hungary, and signals its global influence ambitions.
Taiwan's semiconductor industry, producing over 90% of advanced chips, is vital yet vulnerable due to geopolitical tensions with China. Taiwan aims to maintain its lead despite challenges.
Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin's 43rd meeting underscores deepening China-Russia ties, with China boosting Russia's defence industry despite Western concerns and sanctions.
Taiwan's new president faces Chinese aggression, mirroring tactics used against Japan and the Philippines. The US may need to boost support to counter these grey-zone threats.
Ferdinand Marcos shifts the Philippines' foreign policy back to the U.S., condemns China's actions in the South China Sea, and strengthens military ties with the U.S., Japan, and Australia.
China is using forced labour to control Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang, with Western governments blocking imports from the region. Labour transfers have surged, complicating supply chain integrity.
Russia's UN actions threaten council's effectiveness, while China benefits and subtly supports reshaping global order, challenging Western norms and influencing power dynamics.
Economists Zhou Qiren and Zhang Bin brief Xi Jinping on economic reforms, advocating for lower interest rates, diverse business ecosystems, and job creation for graduates.

China has become a scientific leader, excelling in fields like AI and plant biology, surpassing the US and EU in high-impact research, but still faces challenges in basic science and research quality.
The "global south" seeks more global influence, with China leading but facing challenges. India, Brazil, South Africa, and Gulf states also vie for power, driven by diverse interests.
Huawei's profits surged 564% despite US sanctions, driven by home-grown tech, R&D investment, and diversification into consumer devices, cloud computing, and energy sectors.
The "Beijing consensus" offers a state-led growth model appealing to many developing countries, but its success may be unique to China. Discover why autocratic leaders find it attractive.
African leaders are courting China, Russia, and the UAE for investment, balancing infrastructure gains with risks of debt, corruption, and instability, echoing Cold War-era challenges.
China's stockmarket rises 12% as state-owned institutions buy shares, halting IPOs and causing private capital to retreat. Focus on biotech and AI grows, but exit rates remain low.
China's leaders aim to reduce regional inequality, but inland areas lag behind coastal regions. Efforts include infrastructure projects and controversial policies, yet challenges persist.
India and China have reduced poverty through different methods. China focused on land reforms and education, while India used welfare programmes. India's data accuracy is questioned.
China's Prime Minister Li Qiang visits Australia to mend ties, easing past tensions. Despite this, Australia stays firm on defence pacts with America. Public scepticism towards China persists.
Tibetan children in Qinghai are being sent to state-run boarding schools where Mandarin is the main language, raising concerns about cultural assimilation and coercion by the Chinese government.
Thousands protested in Taiwan against new legislative oversight powers. The Democratic Progressive Party sees it as a power grab, while opposition claims it boosts accountability.
Japanese businesses are thriving with profits and the Nikkei 225 soaring, but face challenges from Sino-American tensions, shifting production, and competition in China.
American student numbers in China rise post-pandemic, with top US universities resuming programmes. Despite mutual suspicion, experts stress the importance of these exchanges to ease tensions.
The yuan's global influence remains modest, lagging behind the Canadian dollar in reserves. Predictions of its rise have not materialised, and East Asian currencies are not anchored to it.
Entrepreneurs in China face shifting political priorities. Ningxia's halal ambitions were curbed by state directives, now focusing on high-tech and agriculture within security bounds.
The Sun Yat-sen Memorial House in Macau, owned by Taiwan, displays Taiwanese symbols despite being in China, highlighting historical tensions and fears of property seizure by Beijing.
Chinese nationalists use AI to create deepfake videos of Russian women praising China and criticising Russian men. These videos, which violate personal rights, prompt new regulations.
Kung fu's popularity is soaring in Africa, driven by social media stars, Nollywood films, and clubs across the continent. This marks a rare cultural success for China in Africa.
Chinese consumers spent $6.7bn on imported durians last year, making it China's top fresh-fruit import. Rising demand, high prices, and "durian diplomacy" shape this booming market.

Western fast-food giants are losing ground in China to local brands like Tastien and Luckin Coffee, which attract cost-conscious consumers with lower prices and local flavours. Investors are keen on these domestic chains, but retail growth in China is slowing, raising sustainability concerns.

title: Global trade dynamics shift as countries face economic challenges, new trade deals, and geopolitical tensions, affecting growth and market stability.

details.text: Britain risks being poorer per person than Poland within a decade due to poor growth. Both major parties focus on economic revival, but challenges like low productivity and Brexit persist.
The WTO is paralysed, globalisation is reversing, and countries are escalating trade sanctions and subsidies, risking economic gains and poverty reduction from global integration.
Countries are forging new trade deals, focusing on digital services and supply chains, bypassing traditional frameworks. Emerging economies aim to reduce reliance on China.
The EU imposes tariffs on Chinese EVs, sparking fears of retaliation from Beijing. German carmakers worry, while Chinese firms plan European factories to counteract the impact.
Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan's chip industries fear US-China tensions could disrupt global supply chains, making America's push to "reshore" semiconductor production costly and impractical.
The World Bank's recalculation of purchasing power parities reveals an extra $7 trillion in global GDP, making China's economy 25% larger than America's and boosting Russia's and Ukraine's economies.
Raiffeisen's Russian profits have tripled to €1.8bn since 2021, despite geopolitical tensions. EU banks face risks from asset seizures and sanctions, making their future uncertain.
Baby-boomers hold 52% of US wealth but are saving, not spending, affecting global growth, inflation, and interest rates. Their habits reshape economic expectations and markets.

Foreign investors are pulling out of India despite its growth, due to complex tax changes and regulatory hurdles. Local investors stay confident, but foreign funds find the environment too unpredictable.
Private credit firms, facing high interest rates and competition, are lowering loan costs and offering flexible terms. The market is evolving, with a shift towards specialised debt pools.
The Texas Stock Exchange secures $120m from BlackRock and Citadel, challenging NYSE with flexible listing rules and electronic trading, making Dallas a new hub for equities.
Marc-William Palen's "Pax Economica" traces left-wing free trade from Cobden to Hull, contrasts it with protectionism, and examines its impact on poverty, welfare, and global conflict.
Kenya, now the third-largest avocado exporter, benefits from ideal farming conditions and rising European demand, but faces challenges in quality standards and shipping logistics.
Luciano Benetton steps down amid financial woes, replaced by turnaround expert Claudio Sforza. Benetton faces €1bn losses and fierce online competition. Can Sforza revive the brand?
We seek a London-based global correspondent to cover policy, economics, and politics. Strong economics knowledge and data analysis experience preferred. Apply by April 5th, 2024.

title: Europe faces political upheaval with rising populism, security threats from Russia, and potential shifts in EU leadership and policies.

details.text: Emmanuel Macron's snap parliamentary vote is a risky move after poor EU election results, echoing past political gambles. This could impact Europe's stability amid ongoing crises.
Europe faces a security crisis with Russia's aggression, Ukraine's struggles, and potential loss of US support. Can Europe bolster its defence and fill the nuclear gap?
The Conservative Party faces a potential historic defeat, with predictions of holding as few as 66 seats. Voter dissatisfaction and internal strife threaten their future direction.
The 80th D-Day anniversary saw veterans honoured, Zelensky drawing WWII-Ukraine parallels, Macron warning of democracy's fragility, and France pledging jets to Ukraine amid allied tensions.
European elections in June may cause EU political gridlock, risking global impacts on Ukraine support, trade, and climate goals, amid rising populism and national instability.
Right-wing populist parties are gaining power across Europe, opposing immigration, Islam, and the EU. Leaders are moderating their messages to win elections, raising questions about Europe's future.

Germany's business leaders warn that the rise of the anti-immigrant AfD threatens the economy, with potential severe impacts if Germany exits the EU, echoing France's experience with the National Rally.

Sweden joins NATO, ending 200 years of neutrality, driven by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Europe and America unite against China but differ in approach, with US elections possibly escalating tensions.
Rishi Sunak sets a July 4th election date. Polls show Labour leading by 20 points, with the Conservatives facing a steep decline, especially in key "red wall" areas.
Emmanuel Macron calls for snap elections after his party's poor EU results, aiming to counter Marine Le Pen's National Rally. Markets react negatively, echoing Chirac's 1997 gamble.
Nationalist parties gained ground in France and Germany during the European Parliament elections, but the centre-right still leads, ensuring continuity in key EU policies and leadership.
Populist parties surged in France and Germany's EU elections, but a hard-right EU takeover didn't happen. The new parliament leans right, with centrists still strong.

Germany may reinstate conscription to address military recruitment issues, with Defence Minister Pistorius supporting a model like Sweden's. The proposal faces mixed reactions and highlights broader defence strategy concerns.
Labour's Generation K, a diverse, disciplined group of new candidates, aims to reshape British politics with a focus on practical issues and public service, testing Keir Starmer's leadership.
The SNP's support plummets as Labour surges in Scotland, promising change and cooperation. Scottish Conservatives also gain by focusing on health, education, and tax issues.
Britain's election campaign focuses on white voters, who are key due to high registration and turnout. Yet, growing diversity and shifting minority political leanings demand attention.
Keir Starmer aims to transform government inspired by Camden, focusing on decarbonising electricity by 2030 and boosting GDP growth, with a shift to collaborative management.
Belgium's Flemish nationalists gain ground before June elections, but internal divisions and practical hurdles make secession unlikely. The country's fragmented politics persist.
Georgia, once a democratic ally, shifts towards Russia under Bidzina Ivanishvili's influence. Protests, controversial laws, and potential Russian bases threaten its Western aspirations.
Budapest, led by Viktor Orban, is a hub for national conservatism, challenging globalism and promoting family values. This movement, despite internal rifts, is reshaping Western politics.
American veterans, some over 100, joined leaders at Omaha Beach for D-Day's 80th anniversary. French gratitude for Allied efforts remains strong, with 62% supporting US defence in Europe.
The Netherlands' new government, led by centrist Dick Schoof, mixes populism and pragmatism, faces EU conflicts, and risks business relocations due to strict asylum policies.

European countries struggle with military recruitment despite efforts like the Dutch "Dienjaar" programme. Economic, cultural, and historical factors deter young people, but Sweden's conscription model shows promise.
In 1999, Europe seemed strong with the end of Milosevic's campaign and the euro's launch. Yet, events like 9/11 and the euro-zone crisis exposed deep vulnerabilities.
The Liberal Democrats, led by Sir Ed Davey, struggle with low voter recognition and past coalition fallout, despite policies like reducing sewage and increasing nurses. Can tactical voting help them?

Bob Fagan recalls D-Day horrors as leaders honour veterans on its 80th anniversary. Normandy's tourism thrives, and Macron will address French civilian casualties. The event underscores transatlantic unity.
Rishi Sunak's phased smoking ban was halted by a snap election, underscoring the Conservatives' struggle to secure lasting reforms beyond Brexit amid pandemic challenges and cabinet changes.
The ANC is set to lose its majority for the first time since 1994, forcing President Ramaphosa into coalition talks amid economic woes and internal party strife.
Eike Schmidt, ex-director of Uffizi Galleries, runs for Florence mayor, facing Sara Funaro. His campaign targets crime in Le Cascine park, despite his German origins' historical sensitivity.
South Africa's election may force a coalition as ANC support wanes. Despite a dip in democracy, it outshines many African nations. EIU survey shows mixed democratic health across regions.

title: Latin America faces political and economic turmoil, with leaders grappling with corruption, violence, and reform challenges amid significant elections.

details.text: The ANC must choose between a pragmatic alliance with the DA or a populist coalition with the EFF or MK, amid internal divisions and governance failures. Ramaphosa's leadership is at stake.
Mexico faces challenges in healthcare, education, and security under López Obrador. Claudia Sheinbaum, likely next president, must tackle migration, crime, and trade, impacting US relations.
Cyril Ramaphosa's indecision leaves South Africa in crisis. With record unemployment, corruption, and looming elections, will a coalition government save or further destabilise the nation?

Gustavo Petro, Colombia’s first left-wing president, faces opposition to his health, labour, and pension reforms, amid rising violence and political polarisation. Can he balance populism and pragmatism?
Nearly 100 million Mexicans will vote on June 2nd in the largest election in the country's history, deciding the next president and 20,000 other positions, shaping Mexico's political future.
Claudia Sheinbaum wins Mexico's presidency with 58%, securing a supermajority for Morena. She faces fiscal, security, and economic challenges, while markets react nervously to potential changes.
Mexico's largest-ever elections are marred by violence, with nearly 40 candidates killed. Voters will choose the first female president, likely Claudia Sheinbaum, amid security concerns.
Latin America's trade faces hurdles from geography, protectionism, and poor infrastructure, but growth in services like Chile's booming exports offers hope.
Mexico’s president López Obrador’s daily broadcasts mix self-praise, attacks on opponents, and odd moments, boosting his popularity. He urges his likely successor to continue the tradition.
Ecuador's homicide rate has soared due to organised crime linked to cocaine smuggling. Iron-fist policies fail; targeted deterrence and anti-corruption measures are needed to curb violence.
In rural Colombia and Mexico, gangs fill power vacuums left by weak state institutions, enforcing brutal justice and gaining local support, highlighting the failure of government security.
Panama faces political upheaval amid canal water woes, fiscal mismanagement, and corruption. Seven presidential candidates vie for solutions, with outsider Ricardo Lombana gaining traction.
Bolivia's ruling party, MAS, is split between President Arce and ex-President Morales, causing government paralysis and economic woes. The opposition eyes an opportunity amid the chaos.
Chiapas faces surging violence as criminal gangs vie for control. President López Obrador's strategies falter, while rivals Gálvez and Sheinbaum propose new security measures.
President Luis Abinader of the Dominican Republic, with a 70% approval rating, is set for re-election. His anti-corruption efforts and economic policies drive support despite security challenges.
The San José galleon, sunk in 1708, holds treasures worth billions. Colombia's exploration faces ownership disputes, funding issues, and political challenges. Can Spain and Colombia collaborate?
"Analysing Africa, launching May 28th, offers weekly insights into Africa's dynamic changes, key economic role, and cultural impact, with exclusive coverage of South Africa's upcoming election."
The Indian stock market rebounded after Modi formed a pro-business coalition, boosting his reputation. Business leaders remain optimistic despite coalition politics' challenges.

title: New AI models from OpenAI and Google, advanced multi-agent systems, and AI-driven cyber-attacks highlight both the promise and risks of technological advancements.

details.text: OpenAI and Google launch new AI models, while multi-agent systems show promise in problem-solving and various fields, despite risks and challenges in security and computational demands.

A Russian-linked network, CopyCop, used AI to create 19,000 fake news posts in a month, targeting issues like Israel, US politics, and Ukraine. Experts warn of more sophisticated future disinformation.
Ukraine's drones now use AI and optical navigation to counter Russian jamming, with systems like Eagle Eyes and NOGPS enhancing targeting and night flights, offering a crucial edge in warfare.
A Russian ransomware attack on the NHS disrupted blood tests and hospital services, exposing cyber-security flaws and highlighting Britain's vulnerability to critical infrastructure attacks.
Cybercrime costs are rising, but the economic impact of major cyber-attacks is decreasing due to improved security. Recent data shows natural disasters cause far more damage.
Chinese hackers, Volt Typhoon, target US infrastructure to disrupt systems in crises. Cyber-attacks now focus on sabotage, risking major disruptions and societal panic.
Russian intelligence agencies are refining their methods, enhancing propaganda, espionage, and cyber-attacks in Europe and Africa, aiming to exploit Western divisions and bolster influence.
OpenAI's top researchers are leaving, reflecting a broader trend of AI talent spreading across companies. Demand for AI experts is high, with tech giants and startups fiercely competing for talent.
China's AI industry is booming, with top models and fierce price wars. Major firms may dominate, stifling smaller innovators due to funding and chip sanctions.
Elon Musk's AI startup, xAI, raises $6bn, aims to rival OpenAI with Grok model and supercomputer plans, but faces stiff competition and challenges from Musk's other commitments.
Global telecoms face major security risks from outdated SS7 technology, allowing hackers to steal data and spy. Despite some improvements, vulnerabilities persist, urging stronger security measures.
Wind turbine blades have tripled in size, boosting power output but complicating transport. Innovations like 3D-printing and helium airships aim to cut costs and overcome logistical hurdles.

Humanoid robots, backed by $2.3bn since 2020, are being tested by firms like Amazon and Hyundai. Despite progress, they still struggle with complex tasks, but AI advances hint at future breakthroughs.
Robots are advancing with AI, holding conversations, recognising objects, and solving problems. Startups like Covariant and Wayve lead this, but hardware still lags behind software progress.
Melanie Reid regained hand movement using ARCEX, a non-invasive device that boosts brain-muscle signals. Developed by Grégoire Courtine, it shows promise for treating paralysis.
Nvidia's stock split reflects its soaring value, but traditional valuation methods seem outdated for tech giants. Economists debate if future dividends or optimism drive prices.
BASF and partners are electrifying high-temperature chemical processes to cut emissions, joining a broader industry shift. Innovations and falling green electricity costs drive this change.
China is leading in flying car tech with EHang's EH216-S, mass production, and plans for extensive eVTOL infrastructure by 2025, aiming for flying-taxi services.
Tim Cook's Apple faces slowing iPhone sales and AI competition. New "Apple Intelligence" strategy integrates AI while ensuring privacy, aiming to boost user experience and device upgrades.
G42, a UAE firm, aims to make the region an AI hub with healthcare and energy applications, backed by $1.5bn from Microsoft. It faces competition and profitability challenges.
Elon Musk's potential $46 billion Tesla pay package, nearly 300 times higher than the top US CEO's, was struck down by a judge. Tesla's board seeks investor support to reaffirm it.
Robert Hannigan's book reveals how diverse thinking and unconventional methods drive innovation in intelligence work, highlighting historical and modern examples of success.

Professional poker players' strategies can guide investors on when to sell stocks. Annie Duke explains biases and suggests treating buying and selling equally, tracking decisions, and setting strict exit criteria.
Lando Norris's determination and McLaren's strategic upgrades have propelled the team to third in the constructors' championship, challenging Red Bull's dominance.
Art-secured lending has surged as auction houses fill gaps left by banks, making art-backed loans more accessible. Young collectors leverage art for financial reasons amid a bearish market.
Discover how China revolutionised typing Chinese characters, from early typewriters to modern pinyin systems, and its impact on global computing, as explored in Thomas Mullaney's book.
ExxonMobil, rebounding with rising oil prices, launches a $60bn takeover, sues activists over emissions, and secures strong shareholder support despite ESG backlash.

title: Efforts to end Sudan's civil war, the erosion of judicial independence in Hong Kong, and the plight of Rohingya refugees highlight the complex challenges in authoritarian regimes.

details.text: A diverse Sudanese coalition, led by ex-PM Abdalla Hamdok, convenes in Addis Ababa to end the civil war and push for civilian rule, aiming to unite major political and neutral armed groups.
The Rwandan genocide's legacy, the faltering "Responsibility to Protect" principle, and geopolitical rivalries hinder effective international intervention in ongoing global conflicts.
Hong Kong's Tiananmen vigil, once the largest, is now banned. New laws suppress dissent, leading to arrests and convictions of pro-democracy activists. The city feels resigned and helpless.
Three foreign judges resigned from Hong Kong's top court, citing China's oppressive political climate. Their exit underscores the erosion of judicial independence under the national-security law.
Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh are being forced by gangs to fight for Myanmar’s junta, which once persecuted them, worsening their plight and inflaming ethnic tensions in Rakhine state.
International courts are active, targeting leaders like Putin and Israeli officials. Yet, geopolitical rivalries and UN paralysis hinder accountability, say human-rights activists.
Fourteen Hong Kong activists were convicted of subversion for holding a 2020 primary election. This marks the largest national-security trial since Beijing's law was imposed.
Ukrainian men risk death to escape conscription, swimming to Romania. Smugglers profit as border security tightens. Survivors like Matviy seek new lives in Europe.
Independent journalists in India use YouTube to challenge Prime Minister Modi, gaining millions of followers despite press freedom declines and government attempts to curb online dissent.
Vietnam's Communist Party faces turmoil as top officials are fired for corruption. Anti-graft efforts by Nguyen Phu Trong expose deep corruption, risking stability and foreign investment.
The article critiques selective condemnation of imperialism, highlighting Soviet oppression and the horrors of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, while challenging simplistic views of colonialism.
Aharon Barak, Israel's former supreme court president, remains divisive for expanding judicial power. His appointment to defend Israel at the International Court of Justice stirs controversy.
Former Kazakh minister Kuandyk Bishimbayev received a 24-year sentence for murdering his partner, sparking national outrage and new domestic violence laws.

Delisha Boyd's bill for surgical castration of child-rapists sparks debate in Louisiana, facing opposition from black Democrats and medical professionals, but gaining support from tough-on-crime Republicans.

title: The U.S. is intensifying its focus on space warfare with China and Russia, while innovations like SpaceX's Starship and the AirFish are pushing the boundaries of space and aviation technology.

details.text: The U.S. is worried about space warfare with China and Russia. Space Command monitors threats, while the 1967 treaty's gaps fuel a competitive space race. The stakes for military dominance are high.
SpaceX's Starship completes a key test flight, surviving re-entry with damage, marking progress towards full reusability. Data will refine designs for future Moon and Mars missions.
The AirFish, inspired by Soviet Ekranoplans, flies just above water, making it a fast, efficient ferry. Built by ST Engineering AirX, it is cheaper and more versatile than seaplanes.
Scientists suggest a "Wall of Death" track for Moon-dwellers to run horizontally, mimicking Earth's gravity to prevent muscle and bone loss. NASA's Artemis Base Camp may adopt this idea.
Enigma Labs' app has logged 15,000 UFO sightings, mostly in Anglophone countries. With growing US support for UAP research, these phenomena could impact air safety and science.

title: America faces a worsening public health crisis with rising drug-related deaths, a new avian flu case, and increasing marijuana use, while new vaccines offer hope against malaria in Africa.

details.text: The fentanyl crisis in America worsens with 75,000 deaths yearly. Despite US efforts, smuggling persists, driven by Mexican cartels and Chinese chemicals. Global impact grows.
The CDC confirmed a second H5N1 avian flu case in America, linked to dairy cows. The virus, deadly in half of human cases, spreads among animals, raising pandemic concerns.
New vaccines and innovations offer hope against malaria in Africa, but challenges like drug resistance and climate change persist. Eradication efforts continue to aim for a malaria-free future.
Ireland and Estonia have Europe's highest drug-related death rates, driven by opioids. Rising deaths among older users and potential heroin shortages could spark a crisis similar to America's.
The Supreme Court's Dobbs decision led to 14 states banning abortion, spiking permanent contraception rates among young Americans. This trend raises concerns about sterilisation regret.
Marijuana use is rising in America, with daily users now outnumbering daily drinkers. This trend raises health and economic concerns as more states consider legalisation.
Northern Ireland's health-care crisis sees patients waiting over a year, emergency delays causing deaths, and a surge in private care. NHS underfunding and staff shortages worsen the issue.
